10.1016/j.apcata.2022.118486 The Authors Fig. 1 Carbon yields of aromatics and gas products versus TOS over fresh H-ZSM-5/Al2O3 catalyst. Reaction conditions: catalyst particle size of 1.2–1.8 mm, catalyst loading of 10 g, catalyst bed temperature of 550 °C, atmospheric pressure, N2 flow of 50 ml min-1, WHSV of co- feeds of 1 h-1, and glycerol/oleic acid weight ratio of 45:55. Fig. 1 Fig. 2 Carbon yields of aromatics and selectivity of the individual BTX components versus TOS over fresh and regenerated H-ZSM-5/Al2O3 catalysts. Reaction conditions: catalyst particle size of 1.2–1.8 mm, catalyst loading of 10 g, catalyst bed temperature of 550 °C, atmospheric pressure, N2 flow of 50 ml min-1, WHSV of co-feeds of 1 h-1, and a glycerol/oleic acid weight ratio of 45:55. Fig. 2 Fig. 3 TG-DTG curves of used H-ZSM-5/Al2O3 catalysts. Fig. 3 Fig. 4 Elemental (Al, Si, and C) maps by TEM-EDX of the used and regenerated H-ZSM-5/Al2O3 catalysts. Fig. 5 Fig. 6 N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms (A), BJH mesopore size distribution (B), and NLDFT micropore size distribution (C) of fresh, used, and regenerated H-ZSM-5/Al2O3 catalysts. The catalytic co-conversion of glycerol and oleic acid (45/55 wt%) to bio-based aromatics (benzene, toluene, and xylenes, bio-BTX) over a technical H-ZSM-5/Al2O3 catalyst in a fixed-bed reactor was investigated with special attention to catalyst deactivation phenomena. The spent catalysts after a time on stream (TOS) of 12 h were regenerated by an ex-situ oxidative treatment to remove coke and reused for another run. In total, 5 reaction-regeneration cycles were performed. The performance and characteristics of the fresh and regenerated catalysts were determined to identify and quantify the effects of co-feeding on catalyst stability and regenerability. The performance of the catalyst changes upon the number of reaction-regeneration cycles. Despite a negative effect on the peak BTX yield, a remarkable improvement in catalyst stability was found, leading to higher BTX productivity (1260–1505 gBTX gcat -1 for the regenerated catalysts during a TOS of 12 h vs. 834 gBTX gcat -1 for the fresh one during a life-time of 11 h). Detailed catalyst characterization studies show irreversible changes in the catalyst structure after reaction-regeneration cycle(s), such as textural property, crystal structure, framework, and acidity, which impact catalyst performance. Graphical Abstract ga1 Keywords Glycerol Oleic acid Bio-aromatics Irreversible deactivation H-ZSM-5/Al2O3 1 Introduction The catalytic conversion of biomass to bio-based aromatics (benzene, toluene, and xylenes, abbreviated as bio-BTX) is an attractive field of research and aims to valorize waste streams and green up the aromatics industry. The effects of the type of biomass (including lignocellulosic biomass and the model compounds), processing options (e.g., gasification, pyrolysis, and hydrolysis), reactor types (e.g., fluidized bed and fixed bed), and type of catalysts (e.g., metal oxides and zeolites) on the yields of BTX have been reported [1]. So far, all processes are at a low technology readiness level (TRL, e.g., of 2–5) with only a few reports on pilot and demo plants [2]. Among them, the catalytic conversion of biomass over H-ZSM-5-based catalyst via either an in-situ or ex-situ mode shows good potential for scale-up, though relatively low bio-BTX yield (e.g., < 30 C.% on a carbon basis) and rapid catalyst deactivation (e.g., life-time of a few hours) [3,4], are still major challenges [5]. The catalytic conversion of biomass to BTX using pyrolysis approach is generally performed at moderate temperatures (e.g., 400–600 °C) in the absence of O2, under which conditions the biomass is converted by several reactions such as deoxygenation (-H2O, -CO2, and -CO), cracking, and condensation to the desired BTX [6]. Examples of biomass feeds showing high potential for the production of bio-based aromatics are crude glycerol (mainly co-produced in biodiesel industry with an estimated global amount in 2020 of ca. 41.9 billion liters [7]), non-edible vegetable oils (including waste cooking oil with an annual production of ca. 16.5 million tons [8]) and others [9–11]. Typically zeolites and particularly H-ZSM-5 are used as catalysts, attributed to the presence of acidic sites (Lewis and Brønsted acidity) and small pores leading to shape selectivity [12]. Modification of H-ZSM-5 with metals has shown to be an effective method to increase the BTX yields (e.g., a 40% yield increase over Ga/ZSM-5 compared to pristine H-ZSM-5 [13]). In addition, it has been shown that the use of co-feeds with high C/Heff numbers [14–27] is an attractive option to increase BTX yields. We have recently reported a synergistic effect on catalyst performance for the conversion of glycerol and various co-feeds (including fatty acids, alcohols, and alkanes) over an H-ZSM-5/Al2O3 (60/40 wt%) catalyst such as an increased peak BTX carbon yield, prolonged catalyst life-time, higher total BTX productivity, and the improved catalyst regenerability [28]. For instance, for glycerol only, a peak BTX yield of 19.5 C.% and a total BTX productivity of 426 mgBTX g-1 catalyst during a life-time of 8.5 h was observed. [29]. Catalyst performance was improved when using oleic acid as the feed, giving a peak BTX yield of 22.8 C.% and a total BTX productivity of 739 mgBTX g-1 catalyst during a life-time of 6.5 h [30]. Remarkably, upon co-feeding glycerol and oleic acid (45/55 wt%), catalyst performance was substantially better than for the individual feeds, and a peak BTX yield of 26.7 C.% and a total BTX productivity of 834 mgBTX g-1 catalyst during catalyst life-time (11 h) was obtained [28]. As such, it is of interest to perform a comprehensive study on the co-feeding of glycerol and oleic acid (45/55 wt%) over a technical H-ZSM-5/Al2O3 catalyst to elucidate the effect of co-feeding on catalyst stability and regenerability, and in particular on the changes of catalyst characteristics after multiple reaction-regeneration cycles. For this purpose, 5 reaction-regeneration cycles were performed and the used and regenerated catalysts were characterized by a variety of analytical techniques. The performance data and the deactivation characteristics are compared with those for the individual feeds (glycerol [29] and oleic acid [30]) using identical experimental and characterization protocols. Such detailed studies have not been reported in the literature. Typically, the reported co-feeding studies with biomass involve studies at mg-g scale in batch set-ups or using analytical instruments (e.g., a pyroprobe) and mass balance data are absent [14–17,19–23,25,26]. Only a few studies have been reported at a slightly larger scale in continuous fixed-bed [18] and fluidized-bed [27] reactors. However, here typically only short time on stream experiments (TOS, e.g., of 3 h [18]) were reported without monitoring catalyst deactivation [31]. Besides, catalyst regeneration/reuse and catalyst performance data after regeneration have not been reported yet. These catalyst performance data and particularly those related to deactivation phenomena are of pivotal importance for the design of reactor and regeneration systems for the catalytic conversion of glycerol and other biomass feeds to BTX in (future) biorefineries [32]. 2 Experimental section 2.1 Materials A granular H-ZSM-5/Al2O3 catalyst (60/40 wt%, ɸ 1.2–1.8 mm, prepared from H-ZSM-5 with a SiO2/Al2O3 molar ratio of 28 and boehmite) was supplied by Yangzhou Baisheng Catalyst Co., Ltd., PR China. The as-received catalyst was calcined at 600 °C (with a ramp of 1 °C min-1) for 8 h in a muffle furnace (LT 9/11/P330, Nabertherm GmbH). This calcined catalyst is denoted as the Fresh catalyst and it was stored in a vacuum desiccator (Bel-Art™ F42400–2141, BEL-ART - SP Scienceware & HB Instruments), which was filled with silica gel (Product No. 11418580, Fisher Scientific Nederlands). Glycerol (> 99.5% purity, s.g. 1.26) was supplied by Boom BV, The Netherlands (product no. 76050770.5000). Oleic acid (> 95% purity) was supplied by Fischer Scientific Netherlands (product no. O/0200/17). n-Nonane, ethanol, and tetrahydrofuran (THF), all of analytical grade, were supplied by Sigma-Aldrich. The gases (e.g., N2, 99.999% purity) and liquid N2 and Ar were supplied by Linde. 2.2 Catalytic co-conversion of glycerol/oleic acid The catalytic co-conversion of glycerol and oleic acid (45/55 wt%) was performed in a continuous fixed-bed reactor (Fig. S1), which has been designed and optimized for catalytic conversion of glycerol [29]. The as-received glycerol (4.5 g h-1) and oleic acid (5.5 g h-1) were fed separately to the unit using syringe pumps (NE-1010, Prosense B.V.) in combination with 100-ml gastight syringes (Hamilton, part no. 86020). The preheaters were filled with quartz wool (VWR international, Part No. BEHRB00027716) and maintained at 300 (for glycerol) and 350 °C (for oleic acid). N2 gas (25 ml min-1 each) was used as the carrier gas to transfer both the glycerol and oleic acid to a filter/mixer and subsequently to the catalytic reactor, which was loaded with 10 g of fresh catalyst and maintained at 550 °C. The reaction was performed at atmospheric pressure for a TOS of 12 h. After leaving the reactor, the vapors were sent to a 3-stage condensation-separation system and the liquid product was collected for a period of 30 min. After 30 min, the collected liquid was removed, during which the vapors exiting the reactor were sent to a second 3-stage condensation-separation system. This sequence was repeated every 30 min 2.3 Product analysis The liquid products after reaction were biphasic (organic and water layer, Fig. S2) and were mixed with a stock solution consisting of ca. 2 x 104 ppm of n-nonane in ethanol/THF (10/90 vol%) to obtain a homogeneous sample. A GC-MS (6890/5973, Hewlett-Packard) and a dedicated GC-FID (5890, Hewlett-Packard) equipped with the same Rtx-1701 column (30 m × 0.25 mm × 0.25 µm, Restek) were used to qualify and quantify the components in the samples. For the latter, the relative response factors of the individual aromatics to n-nonane were applied. The C, H, and O amounts in the samples were analyzed using an elemental analyzer (EuroEA3000, Eurovector). The content of H2O in the samples was determined using a Karl-Fischer titration with a potentiometric titrator (702 SM Titrino, Metrohm). The gaseous products were collected in 5-L FlexFoil Plus sample bags (supplied by SKC Ltd., part no. 207104) and analyzed using a dedicated GC-TCD (5890, Hewlett-Packard) equipped with a CP-PoraBOND Q column (50 m × 0.53 mm × 10 µm, Varian) and an HP-Molsieve column (30 m x 0.53 mm x 50 µm, Agilent). Before and after analyses, the GC-TCD was calibrated with a standard gas mixture (supplied by Westfalen AG, product no. G322243). The product yield and the individual BTX selectivity (both on a carbon basis), and the total BTX productivity were calculated using Eqs. (1) – (3). The catalyst life-time is defined as the TOS when the carbon yield of BTX is < 1 C.% [28,33]. The predicted performance data (peak carbon yield of BTX and total BTX productivity) for the catalytic co-conversion of glycerol and oleic acid (45/55 wt%) are based on the carbon fractions of the individual feeds (glycerol of 30% and oleic acid of 70%) and catalyst performance for the individual feeds (extracted from Refs. [29,30]) using Eq. (4). The turnover number (TON) was calculated using Eq. (5) [29,33]. (1) Yield ( C . % ) = mol of carbon in the individual product mol of carbon in the co - feed × 100 (2) BTX selectivity ( % ) = mol of individual BTX component mol of total BTX product × 100 (3) Total BTX productivity ( mg BTX g catalyst − 1 ) = gram of BTX produced gram of catalyst loaded in the reactor (4) Predicted performance data = 0.3 × experimental performance data for glycerol + 0.7 × experimental performance data for oleic acid (5) TON ( mol BTX mol acid site − 1 ) = total BTX production at a specific TOS Brønsted acid sites according to Pyridine IR analysis 2.4 Reaction-regeneration cycles After the reaction, the reactor was cooled to room temperature under an N2 flow (50 ml min-1) and the used catalyst (denoted as Used-i catalyst, in which i represents the number of reaction-regeneration cycles) was unloaded from the reactor followed by an ex-situ oxidative regeneration in a muffle furnace (same as for catalyst calcination). The used catalyst was placed in a Haldenwanger porcelain crucible (90-ml, supplied by Fisher Scientific Nederlands, product no. 10493081) and was heated to 680 °C (1 °C min-1) under air. The regeneration lasted for 12 h and the regenerated catalyst was denoted as the Regenerated-i catalyst. The regenerated catalyst was placed in the reactor and reused using the same protocol as for the fresh catalyst (vide supra). In total, 5 cycles of reaction-regeneration were performed. 2.5 Catalyst characterization All the fresh, used, and regenerated catalysts were ground into homogeneous powdery samples (< 40 µm) using an agate mortar and pestle (IDL GmbH & Co. KG) before characterization. The same protocols used for the characterizations of the used and regenerated catalysts for catalytic conversion of glycerol [29] and oleic acid [30] were applied (vide infra). Physisorption experiments with N2 (at 77 K) and Ar (at 87 K) were performed on an ASAP 2420 (Micromeritics). The sample was degassed at 450 °C for 4 h before the analysis. The Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) method [34] was applied to calculate the specific surface area (SBET). The total pore volume (Vpore) was estimated by a single point N2 desorption at P/P0 of 0.98. The Barrett-Joyner-Halenda (BJH) method [35] was applied to calculate the mesopore size distribution (meso-PSD) and mesopore volume (Vmesopore) from the N2 isotherms. Non-Localized Density Functional Theory (NLDFT [36]) was applied to calculate the micropore size distribution (micro-PSD) and micropore volume (Vmicropore) from the Ar isotherms. Powder X-ray diffraction (XRD) analysis was conducted on a D8 Advance Powder Diffractometer (Bruker, Germany), which was operated at 40 kV and 40 mA and with Cu Kα radiation (λ = 1.5418 Å). XRD spectra were recorded using an LYNXEYE detector (1D mode). The relative crystallinity of the catalyst was calculated according to an ASTM D5758–01 method (Eq. (6)), in which the height (H) of the diffraction peak at 2θ of 24.37° for the sample was compared with that for the Fresh catalyst. (6) Relative crystallinity ( % ) = H catalyst H fresh catalyst × 100 Transmission electron microscopy (TEM) images were taken on a Tecnai T20 Transmission Electron Microscope (FEI) equipped with a Gatan 626 cryo-stage working at 200 keV. Energy Dispersive X-ray (EDX) analysis was carried out using an X-Max T80 SDD EDX Detector (Oxford). The sample was dispersed in ethanol under ultrasonication followed by deposition on a carbon-coated copper grid. Magic angle spinning solid-state nuclear magnetic resonance (MAS ssNMR) analysis was performed on an AV-I 750 MHz spectrometer (Bruker) with a magnetic field of 17.6 Tesla and a MAS rate of 54.74 kHz. The sample in the rotor was scanned 1024 times. The chemical shifts of Al(NO3)3 and tetramethylsilane (TMS) were used as the reference for 27Al and 29Si MAS ssNMR spectra, respectively. Temperature-programmed desorption of ammonia (NH3-TPD) was performed on an AutoChem II (Micromeritic). The sample was pretreated at 550 °C under He (50 ml min-1) for 1 h followed by cooling to 100 °C to adsorb NH3 by flowing NH3/He (1.0 vol%, 50 ml min-1) for 1 h and purging by flowing He (50 ml min-1) for 1 h. A calibrated TCD was used to detect the desorbed NH3. Pyridine-IR analysis was performed on a Nicolet 6700 FTIR Spectrometer. The pressed sample pellets (ca. 50 mg, φ 10 mm) were loaded into a tailor-made cell and pretreated under vacuum (< 10-3 bar) at 400 °C for 4 h followed by the adsorption of a saturated pyridine vapor at 25 °C. After the evacuation at 160 °C for 30 min, the Pyridine-IR spectrum was recorded. Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) was conducted on a TGA 4000 (PerkinElmer). The sample was loaded into a ceramic crucible, which was heated from 50 °C to 800 °C (10 °C min-1) under synthetic air (50 ml min-1). As a reference, the empty crucible was also measured using the same protocol. Elemental analyses were carried out on a EuroEA3000 Elemental Analyzer (Eurovector). Sulfanilamide (supplied by Elemental Microanalysis Ltd.) was used as the reference. The analyses were performed in duplicate and the average data are reported. Oxygen content is by difference. 3 Results and discussions 3.1 Fresh catalyst performance The catalytic co-conversion of glycerol/oleic acid (45/55 wt%) was performed in a fixed-bed reactor at 550 °C, H-ZSM-5/Al2O3 (60/40 wt%), a catalyst loading of 10 g, and a WHSV of the co-feeds of 1 h-1 [29,30]. At a short TOS (e.g., of 1.5 h), the major liquid products detectable by GC-MS are aromatics such as BTX and polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons (Fig. S3). At a prolonged TOS (e.g., 12 h), the major liquid products are oxygenates (e.g., acetaldehyde and hydroxyacetone), alkanes/alkenes (e.g., octadecane and dodecene), and unconverted co-feeds (Fig. S4). These changes in product distribution upon prolonged TOS indicate that the H-ZSM-5/Al2O3 catalyst becomes inactive with TOS for aromatics formation, mainly due to coke formation on the catalyst surface (vide infra). To monitor catalyst deactivation, the carbon yields of the major aromatics and gas products versus TOS are shown in Fig. 1. The yields of BTX (Fig. 1-a) and the other major aromatics (Fig. 1-b) increase with TOS in the initial stage of the reaction, which is likely related to the start-up of the reactor. The aromatics yield reaches a maximum value of 31.2 C.% (BTX yield of 26.7 C.%) at a TOS of 2 h and afterward gradually decreases, e.g., to a value below 1.4 C.% at a TOS of 11 h. Similarly, the carbon yields of C1 - C3 products show volcano-shape curves (e.g., a peak propane yield of 5.9 C.% at TOS of 3 h, Fig. 1-d). However, the yields of CO and CO2 are rather stable after a TOS of 2 h (ca. 3.1 C.% and 1.4 C.%, Fig. 1-c). These results indicate that after a long TOS, the H-ZSM-5/Al2O3 catalyst is considerably deactivated for aromatization and cracking while deactivation levels for decarbonylation and decarboxylation (forming CO and CO2) are by far less prominent. Due to catalyst deactivation, the cumulative aromatics yield after 11 h of TOS is rather low (ca. 12.8 C.%, Fig. S5-B) (Fig. 1 and Table 1, Entry 3). Besides the targeted aromatics, carbon also ends up in CO (yield of ca. 4.5 C.%), CO2 (yield of ca. 1.8 C.%), gaseous C1-C3 hydrocarbons (yield of ca. 22.8 C.%), and other organic products in the liquid phase (yield of ca. 54.8 C.%) (Fig. S5-B). Besides, the total BTX productivity of ca. 834 mg g-1 catalyst (Table 1, Entry 3) is also rather low considering performance metrics established for sustainable catalysts in (bio-)refineries (e.g., > 1 kgproduct g-1 catalyst) [32]. As such, catalyst regeneration and recycle are inevitable to meet these catalyst performance criteria. For this purpose, the used H-ZSM-5/Al2O3 catalyst was regenerated by an oxidative treatment, followed by recycling to the reactor to assess the potential for catalyst regenerability. In total, 5 reaction-regeneration cycles were performed and the results are shown in Table 1. 3.2 Five reaction-regeneration cycles A standard ex-situ oxidative protocol (heating to 680 °C at a ramp rate of 1 °C min-1 under air followed by oxidation at 680 °C for 12 h and cooling to room temperature at a ramp rate of −1 °C min-1 in an oven) was used to regenerate the catalyst after TOS [29,30]. After the ex-situ oxidative treatment, the regenerated catalyst was evaluated for glycerol-oleic acid co-feeding by following the same protocol as used for testing the fresh catalyst. Similar to the Fresh catalyst, the regenerated catalysts show volcano-shaped BTX carbon yield curves ( Fig. 2-top). Of interest is the slightly lower peak BTX yield (of 18.9 C.%, Fig. 2-top and Table 1, Entry 6) or the Regenerated-1 catalyst, indicating some changes in the catalyst structure after one cycle of reaction-regeneration. However, it is remarkable to observe that the Regenerated-1 catalyst has a significantly improved catalyst stability compared to Fresh catalyst (Fig. 2-top), showing a catalyst life-time exceeding 12 h (Fig. 2-top, Table 1, Entry 6). As a result, the Regenerated-1 catalyst shows a by far higher total BTX productivity of > 1260 mg g-1 catalyst (Table 1, Entry 6) compared to Fresh catalyst. Besides, the regenerated catalysts after 2–4 times of regeneration do not show a further reduction in peak BTX yield (19.8–22.8 C.%, Fig. 2-top, Table 1, Entries 9, 12, and 15) compared to Regenerated-1 catalyst. The total BTX productivity for a TOS of 12 h of the regenerated catalysts after 2–4 times of regeneration (1328–1505 mg g-1 catalyst, Table 1, Entries 9, 12, and 15) are also comparable to that of Regenerated-1 catalyst. These results suggest that beyond 1–2 reaction-regeneration cycles, the H-ZSM-5/Al2O3 catalyst reaches a steady-state regarding catalyst performance, indicating a good potential for multiple catalyst regeneration cycles beyond 5. The selectivity of the individual BTX components over Regenerated-1 catalyst differs from that over the fresh catalyst, in particular in the initial stage of the reaction (TOS of 0–5 h, Fig. 2-bottom). The selectivity of m,p-xylene is increased at the expense of benzene. These selectivity changes are most likely associated with changes in the catalyst structure (e.g., acidity) upon regeneration (vide infra). Of interest is the observation that the selectivity of the individual BTX components for regenerated catalyst after 2–4 times of regeneration are comparable with those over Regenerated-1 catalyst, confirming a steady-state in catalyst performance for the regenerated catalysts after multiple reaction-regeneration cycles. To determine the changes in catalyst structure after regeneration and to obtain catalyst structure-performance relations, the used and regenerated catalysts after the 1st and 5th reaction-regeneration were characterized in detail. 3.3 Changes in catalyst characteristics upon reaction-regeneration cycle(s) 3.3.1 Coke formation Visual inspection of the catalyst after a continuous run for a TOS of 12 h, showed that the catalyst color changed from off-white to black, most likely due to coking [37,38]. This was confirmed by TGA and elemental analyses of the spent catalyst. After the 1st reaction, about 22.9 wt% of coke (by TGA, Fig. 3-top-a, Table 2, Entry 4) or 21.5 wt% of carbon (by elemental analysis, Table 2, Entry 4) was present on Used-1 catalyst. This high amount of coke was also reported for experiments with either glycerol [11,33,39,40] or oleic acid [30]. Of interest is the observation that the coke yield (ca. 3.3 C.% on a carbon basis, Fig. S5-B) is considerably lower than for the conversion of glycerol alone (6.2 C.%, Fig. S15-B) and oleic acid (4.2 C.%, Fig. S16-B). Thus, the co-conversion of glycerol and oleic acid leads to a considerable lowering of the coke yield. TEM-EDX imaging was used to determine the location of the coke on the catalyst. It appears that the coke is non-uniformly distributed in Used-1 catalyst ( Figs. 4-a and S6). This is likely due to the presence of larger amounts of coke in the mesoporous Al2O3 binder structure than in the microporous H-ZSM-5 component [29]. The DTG curve of the Used-1 catalyst (Fig. 3-bottom-a) shows that a relatively high temperature (ca. 553 °C, Table 2) is required to obtain a maximum weight loss rate (TM) for coke combustion, indicating that the coke may be classified as hard. This hard coke likely consists of poly-condensed aromatics and dienes, which are formed at elevated temperatures and long reaction times [41]. This high TM value is comparable to that for the spent catalyst after the conversion of pure glycerol (ca. 554 °C, Table 2) [29] but considerably higher than that for the spent catalyst after the conversion of pure oleic acid (ca. 538 °C, Table 2) [30]. This indicates that the coke on the used catalyst is harder after the conversion of glycerol-containing feed than after the conversion of solely oleic acid. XRD pattern of the Used-1 catalyst shows two diffraction peaks (∇) at 2θ = 23.2 and 45.3 for Used-1 catalyst ( Fig. 5-b), corresponding to a graphitic coke structure [38]. This graphitic coke was also observed on the spent H-ZSM-5/Al2O3 catalysts after the conversion of either pure glycerol [29,42] or oleic acid [30]. According to the TG and DTG curves, the coke on the Used-1 catalyst needs a high temperature, e.g., > 700 °C for complete removal by an oxidation treatment. The regeneration temperature of 680 °C in combination with the extended regeneration time (12 h) used in this study [29,30,33] allows removal of the majority of the coke (ca. 95%), with ca. 1.1 wt% of carbon on Regenerated-1 catalyst remaining (TEM-EDX analysis, Figs. 4-c and S7). Similarly, the coke formed on the Used-5 catalyst is also not uniformly distributed with more coke on the outer layer of the catalyst (Figs. 4-b and S8). Compared to Used-1 catalyst, Used-5 catalyst has less coke deposition, as is evident from TGA (16.8 wt%, Fig. 3-top-a) and elemental analysis (carbon content of 15.7 wt%, Table 1, Entry 10). However, the TM for the coke on Used-5 catalyst (578 °C, Fig. 3-bottom-b) is considerably higher than that of the Used-1 catalyst (553 °C, Fig. 3-bottom-a). This indicates that the coke becomes harder with more reaction-regeneration cycles, likely due to successive reactions (e.g., dehydrogenation) of the remaining coke after each regeneration step. Coke affects the textural properties of the catalysts [43]. For instance, the micropore volume is reduced by 85% (Used-1 versus Fresh, Table 2, Entries 4 and 10) and the acidity [44] is also reduced by 80% for Used-1 (Table 2, Entries 4 and 10). These reductions in catalyst characteristics result in the loss of the catalyst activity for the BTX production after a few hours’ continuous run (Fig. 2). Coke formation though may be considered as reversible catalyst deactivation, as the oxidative regeneration protocols appear to be rather effective to remove the coke, showing very small amount of coke residue (ca. 0.9–1.1 wt% of carbon, Fig. 4-c and -d) on the Regenerated-1 and Regenerated-5 catalysts. 3.3.2 Irreversible changes in catalyst characteristics upon reaction-regeneration cycle(s) The catalyst performance of the regenerated catalysts, particularly the first regeneration cycle, (e.g., peak carbon yield of BTX and catalyst life-time, Table 1), is different from that of the fresh one, indicating irreversible changes in the catalyst structure [11,30,33]. To determine these changes, the regenerated catalysts after 1 and 5 times of regeneration were characterized and the characteristics of the regenerated catalysts were compared with those of the fresh catalyst. The Regenerated-1 and Regenerated-5 catalysts show similar N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms (a combined Type-I and -IV isotherms [45]), BJH mesopore size distributions (in a range of 3–10 nm, related to the mesopores of the Al2O3 binder [29]), and NLDFT micropore size distributions (centered at ca. 0.52 nm, related to the micropores of the H-ZSM-5 zeolite [29,33]), compared to the Fresh catalyst ( Fig. 6-c and -e vs. -a). Nevertheless, important textural properties such as the specific surface area (ca. 7–9%) and the NLDFT micropore volume (17–19%), are reduced for the Regenerated-1 and Regenerated-5 catalysts when compared with the Fresh catalyst (Table 2, Entries 7 and 13). The XRD patterns of the Regenerated-1 and Regenerated-5 catalysts show two relevant peaks (♥) at 2θ = ca. 7.9° and 8.9°, corresponding to the [011] and [200] planes of the H-ZSM-5 zeolite [46]). These are also present in the Fresh catalyst (Fig. 5-c and -e vs. -a). The diffraction peaks (∇) at 2θ = 23.2 and 45.3 from crystalline coke are not present in the two regenerated catalysts, indicating that the oxidative treatment leads to the removal of most of the graphite-like coke. Nevertheless, the relative crystallinity for the Regenerated catalysts is considerably lower than the fresh catalyst (ca. 7% lower for Regenerated-1% and 38% for Regenerated-5 catalysts (Table 2, Entries 7 and 13). These data also imply that successive reaction-regeneration cycles lead to further reductions in crystallinity. The NH3-TPD profiles of the Regenerated-1 and Regenerated-5 catalysts show a broad acid distribution (100–550 °C, Fig. -c and -e). The low-temperature peak (centered at ca. 205 °C) reflects the weak acid sites, whereas the high-temperature peak (a shoulder at ca. 370–380 °C) is indicative of the presence of strong acid sites of the catalysts [47]. Compared to the Fresh catalyst ( Fig. 7-a), the regenerated catalyst, in particular the Regenerated-5 catalyst, shows a considerably reduced number of strong acid sites. This is in good accordance with the pyridine-IR spectra of the catalysts (Fig. S10-bottom), showing a significant reduction in the intensity of the peak at ca. 1545 cm−1, which corresponds to the protonated pyridine on the Brønsted acid sites [48]. As such, the total catalyst acidity (according to NH3-TPD) is decreased with ca. 37% for Regenerated-1% and 69% for the Regenerated-5 catalyst (Table 2, Entries 7 and 13). The decrease in the Brønsted acid sites is by far more pronounced compared to the reduction in Lewis acid sites (e.g., 90% vs. 65% on the Regenerated-5 catalyst, Table 2, Entry 13), leading to a lower molar ratio of the Brønsted acidity/Lewis acidity upon prolonged reaction-regeneration cycles (Table 2, Entries 7 and 13). Compared to the Fresh catalyst, the decrease in Brønsted acidity on the Regenerated-1 catalyst leads to a lower peak BTX yield (18.9 C.% vs. 26.7 C.%, Table 1, Entry 6 vs. 3). However, the turnover number (TON) of the Regenerated-1 catalyst is considerably higher than that of the Fresh one (57.2 vs. 19.4 moltotal BTX molacid site -1). This increase in TON for the regenerated catalyst has been reported before [11,29], and is likely related to the excess of acidic sites on the catalyst at the start of the reaction, which are not all necessary for aromatics formation [11,29,38]. Whereas Brønsted acidic sites are involved in aromatization of intermediates, it is very likely that Lewis acid sites participate heavily in the first steps of the reaction network, namely the deoxygenation of glycerol to C1 (e.g., formaldehyde), C2 (e.g., acetaldehyde), and C3 (e.g., acrolein) oxygenates [33], and deoxygenation of oleic acid to alkenes [30]. This hypothesis is supported by the observed product distribution at longer TOS, where BTX is absent but glycerol conversion is still significant. Thus, Brønsted acid sites are most likely not accessible anymore for catalysis whereas considerable amounts of Lewis acid sites are present [30,33]. These remaining Lewis acid sites are thus responsible for the first step conversion and the formation of the deoxygenated products. Long-time exposure of the zeolitic catalyst at harsh reaction conditions (e.g., a relatively high temperature in combination with steam) during the reaction-regeneration cycle(s) is expected to lead to dealumination of the H-ZSM-5 framework [49,50]. This is indeed confirmed by the 29Si MAS ssNMR data ( Fig. 8-B) for the regenerated catalysts, showing a decrease in the intensity of the weak shoulder peak at δ = ca. − 106 ppm (assigned to the Si(3Si, 1Al) species in the H-ZSM-5 framework [51]). This is evident for the Regenerated-1 (Fig. 8-B-c) and particularly for the Regenerated-5 (Fig. 8-B-d) catalyst when the height of the Si(4Si, 0Al) resonance (at δ = ca. −113 ppm) is plotted at the same level. Thus, we can conclude that the catalyst structure changes during reaction-regeneration cycles. Some of these changes e.g., reduction in micropores and Brønsted acidity are expected to have a negative effect on the peak BTX carbon yield. Indeed, this is observed experimentally and implies that these properties are, essential for the catalytic conversion of glycerol to aromatics [33,38]. However, and remarkably, these changes in catalyst characteristics seem beneficial when considering coke formation. The coke rate seems to be reduced (e.g., a carbon content of 21.5 wt% on the Used-1 catalyst vs. 15.7 wt% on the Used-5 catalyst after TOS of 12 h, Table 2, Entry 4 vs. 10), which is likely related to a reduction in strong acid sites, that are known to be involved in coking processes. Besides, these changes in catalyst characteristics (in particular the reduction in acidity) may also inhibit side reactions (e.g., dealkylation of the produced aromatics), leading to a lower benzene selectivity and a higher m,p-xylene selectivity for the 1st reaction vs. the 5th reaction (Fig. 2-bottom). This is likely related to a reduced and deactivated ‘induction zone’ at the exit of the catalyst bed, in which a further conversion of the products formed in the ‘conversion zone’ leads to changes in the product selectivity [37]. Based on these results, we can conclude that changes in relevant catalyst properties (acidity, crystallinity dealumination) do occur upon regeneration/reuse but do not lead to deterioration of catalyst performance (Fig. 2 and Table 1) [30]. 3.4 Catalytic co-feeding versus performance of the individual feeds It is of interest to compare catalyst performance (Table 1) and irreversible changes in the catalyst structure (Table 2) for the co-feeding experiments with glycerol/oleic acid (45/55 wt%, this work) and the experiments for the individual feeds (glycerol [29] and oleic acid [30]). The catalyst performance data are compiled in Table 1. Here, the predicted values for the co-feeding experiments are calculated using the co-feed ratio and performance data for the individual feeds. Of high interest is the observation that important catalyst performance metrics when using fresh catalysts, such as the peak BTX yield and the total BTX productivity, are considerably higher for the co-feeding experiment than for experiments with the individual feed (Table 1, Entry 3 vs. 1 and 2). Of interest is also the observation that the experimental peak BTX yield and the total BTX productivity for the co-feeding experiments are higher than predicted based on the performance of the individual feeds. As such, these results imply the presence of a synergistic effect [15–17,19–26] between glycerol and oleic acid on catalyst performance. In addition, also catalyst stability is improved for the co-feeding experiments compared with those with individual feeds. For instance, the catalyst life-time is significantly prolonged (from 8.5 for glycerol alone and 6.5 h for oleic acid alone) to 11 h for the co-feeding experiments using a fresh catalyst (Table 1, Entry 3 vs. 1 and 2). Catalyst life-times for the co-feeding experiments using the regenerated catalysts were all longer than 12 h. The exact values could not be determined due to constraints regarding safety in our laboratory, not allowing experiments at TOS beyond 12 h. As such, it is clear that the BTX productivities during a TOS of 12 h over the regenerated catalysts for the catalytic co-feeding experiments are higher than the predicted values (Table 1, Entries 6, 9, 12, and 15), indicating that the regenerability of the catalyst is even improved upon co-feeding. The catalyst characterization data are shown in Table 2. In general, the specific surface area, pore volume (total pore volume and micropore volume), relative crystallinity, acidity (total acidity, Brønsted acidity, and Lewis acidity), and coke (content and TM of DTG) for the regenerated catalysts after 1 and 5 cycles for co-feeding experiments (Table 2, Entries 7 and 13) are in the range for experiments with individual feeds (glycerol: Table 2, Entries 5 and 11 and oleic acid: Table 2, Entries 6 and 12). These results stress that there are no additional irreversible changes in catalyst characteristics upon co-feeding. 4 Conclusions Catalyst performance and catalyst deactivation characteristics for the co-feeding of glycerol and oleic acid to BTX have been determined. Clear changes in catalyst characteristics are observed after 1 and 5 reaction-regeneration cycles, including a decrease in the specific surface area (7–9%), the NLDFT micropore volume (17–19%), relative crystallinity (7–38%), total acidity (37–69%), and dealumination of the H-ZSM-5 framework. These irreversible changes in catalyst characteristics have a negative effect on the peak BTX carbon yield (26.7 C.% vs. 18.9–22.8 C.%) though a very positive effect on prolonging the catalyst life-time (> 12 h vs. 11 h) leading to a considerably higher total BTX productivity (1260–1505 mgBTX g-1 catalyst during a TOS of 12 h) of the regenerated catalysts, compared with those of the fresh one (834 mgBTX g-1 catalyst during a life-time of 11 h). The catalyst recycling results indicate that catalyst regeneration and reuse appear possible, though the number of reaction-regeneration cycles used in this study is still limited to 5. In this respect, future testing with a large number of recycles, e.g., using an FCC-type unit with continuous reaction and catalyst regeneration will be required and these studies are in progress. coredata.dc:description: The catalytic co-conversion of glycerol and oleic acid (45/55 wt%) to bio-based aromatics (benzene, toluene, and xylenes, bio-BTX) over a technical H-ZSM-5/Al2O3 catalyst in a fixed-bed reactor was investigated with special attention to catalyst deactivation phenomena. The spent catalysts after a time on stream (TOS) of 12 h were regenerated by an ex-situ oxidative treatment to remove coke and reused for another run. In total, 5 reaction-regeneration cycles were performed. The performance and characteristics of the fresh and regenerated catalysts were determined to identify and quantify the effects of co-feeding on catalyst stability and regenerability. The performance of the catalyst changes upon the number of reaction-regeneration cycles. Despite a negative effect on the peak BTX yield, a remarkable improvement in catalyst stability was found, leading to higher BTX productivity (1260–1505 gBTX gcat -1 for the regenerated catalysts during a TOS of 12 h vs. 834 gBTX gcat -1 for the fresh one during a life-time of 11 h). Detailed catalyst characterization studies show irreversible changes in the catalyst structure after reaction-regeneration cycle(s), such as textural property, crystal structure, framework, and acidity, which impact catalyst performance.
